title: Michael Owen explains why he "couldn't wait to give it back" after being awarded Ballon d'Or
text:

Michael Owen has admitted he didn't realise the enormity of his achievement when winning the Ballon D'Or and confessed he "couldn't wait to give it back".

The former Liverpool and England striker was awarded the much-coveted after his club's unique treble-winning season in 2001, as well as helping his country to qualify for the 2002 World Cup.

Phil Thompson was taking charge of first-team affairs at Anfield at the time due to an illness to manager Gerard Houllier.

Speaking to the Blood Red podcast , Owen said: "In the dressing room Phil Thompson - who had a big thing at the time for no mobile phones - had a mobile phone in his hand.

"I thought 'that's strange', and then he called me into the corridor outside the dressing room and said 'the gaffer wants to speak to you'.

(Image: Daily Mirror)

"I hadn't heard from him for ages as he was going through his bad illness. He said 'you've won the Ballon d'Or, I wanted to tell you before the game'.

"I was delighted, of course, but I was just zoned in at the time for the game.

"It was only until later on he actually said 'you've don't realise what you've won here, do you?'. I said 'Gaffer I'm proud, honestly I'm pleased', and he said 'no, you don't realise what an achievement this is!'.

(Image: Liverpool Echo)

"And to be honest he was dead right, I didn't. I picked up the trophy in front of the fans at Anfield and I almost couldn't wait to give it them back.

"It was just that type of attitude at the time. Of course I'm a bit older and wiser now, and it does take pride of place at home."

Liverpool had has a momentous season which saw them win the FA Cup, League Cup and UEFA Cup, and followed that up with the Super Cup at the start of the following campaign.

(Image: Mirrorpix)

He also netted a hat-trick in England's 5-1 demolition of rivals Germany.

Owen finished ahead of Real Madrid's Spanish striker Raul and Bayern Munich and Germany goalkeeper Olivier Kahn to claim the award, as well as pipping a host of other names in the top 10.

Thierry Henry, David Beckham and Zinedine Zidane were also in contention, and Owen quipped: "Well, you never get a bad Ballon d'Or line up do you?

"It's always going to be a star-studded list of players.

"I've got the list saved on my phone as a picture just for when I get a bit down, sometimes you can just have a look at that and that was a year when I beat all those players.

"It was a special year, special season, particularly at club level but of course at international level as well. It was amazing, goals flowed."
description: The former Liverpool forward won the prize in 2001 after helping his club earn a unique treble success
